- A comma was added after "First of all" to separate it from the next clause.
- "Fourty-five" was changed to "forty-five" to correct the spelling.

- "Pieceful" was changed to "peaceful" to correct the spelling error.

- "Chose" is replaced with the present tense "choose."
- "Peaceful" is the correct spelling of "pieceful."
- "As" replaces "of." "As" is used to mean "like" in this phrase.

explanation_1:
- "But the problem is" is followed by a clause, so "that" was added to make it a complete sentence.
- "For example" was changed to "like" for more natural and concise phrasing.
- "On Friedy" was corrected to "on Friday."
- "At" was removed as it is not needed in this context.
- "Each supermarkets are" was changed to "every supermarket is" to match subject-verb agreement.
explanation_2:
- Added "that" to introduce a that-clause after the auxiliary verb "is."
- The word "for example" is replaced with the word "like" because this lexical choice is a more suitable equivalent.
- The period is deleted, so the preposition "on" is not capitalized.
- A spelling error was corrected. The correct spelling is "Friday."
- A comma was inserted after "like bread" to mark off this parenthetical information added in the middle of the sentence. A pair of commas are used to enclose this extra information.
- The preposition "at" was deleted because the correct preposition "on" is already included in the sentence.
- The definite article "the" is deleted because the general noun "weekdays" does not require an article before it.
- The phrase "each supermarkets are" is ungrammatical, so it was replaced with "every supermarket is." This also improves sentence fluency.
- - A comma was added after the introductory that-clause, which provides background information for the independent clause following it.

aligned: Regarding <mark>{to=>}</mark> the end-of-conference party , I would suggest <mark>{to wear some=>wearing a}</mark> dress for a woman and an elegant suit for a man , though <mark>{,=>}</mark> it is <mark>{no=>not}</mark> formal <mark>{do=>}</mark> .
explanation_1:
- The preposition "to" is unnecessary in this context and was removed.
- The phrase "wear some dress" was changed to "wearing a dress" for better fluency.
- The comma after "though" was removed because it was unnecessary and disrupted the sentence's flow.
- The word "no" was changed to "not" for correct grammar.
- The word "do" was removed as it added nothing to the sentence and was not grammatically necessary.
explanation_2:
- "Regarding" is the more appropriate preposition in this instance. "To" in this context indicates movement, of which there is none, and is therefore incorrect.
- "To wear some" was corrected to "wearing a" to correct the advice given. When "suggest" is followed by a verb, the verb should use '-ing' or be in its original form preceded by 'you.'
- The comma was removed after "though" because it forms part of the next thought.
- "No" was changed to "not" because it precedes an adjective.
- "Do" was removed from the end of the phrase to increase fluency.

explanation_1:
- The preposition "to" is unnecessary in this context and was removed.
- The phrase "wear some dress" was changed to "wearing a dress" for better fluency.
- The comma after "though" was removed because it was unnecessary and disrupted the sentence's flow.

- "To wear some" was corrected to "wearing a" to correct the advice given. When "suggest" is followed by a verb, the verb should use '-ing' or be in its original form preceded by 'you.'
- The comma was removed after "though" because it forms part of the next thought.
- "No" was changed to "not" because it precedes an adjective.
- "Do" was removed from the end of the phrase to increase fluency.
comments:
The third point in Explanation 2 makes it sound like the comma, not the word "though," forms part of the next thought. 
"It is no formal do" could be a British way of saying "it is not a formal party"; BrE often uses "do" to mean "event," and "it is no [noun]" is not an unheard-of construction (e.g., "that's no moon").

aligned: In your previous letter <mark>{=>,}</mark> you asked <mark>{=>for}</mark> information about interesting <mark>{building=>buildings}</mark> to visit in my country .
explanation_1:
- A comma is entered after "letter" to signal the end of an introductory phrase. Commas are mandatory after introductory phrases consisting of at least four words.
- "For" is inserted between the words "asked" and "information." For serves as a preposition that clarifies the relationship between the latter two words.
explanation_2:
- A comma is necessary after the phrase "previous letter" because it introduces a dependent clause.
- "Asked information" was changed to "asked for information" to correct the grammar.
- "Building" was changed to "buildings" because the original sentence is referring to multiple buildings.

aligned: Without <mark>{=>a}</mark> doubt , discovering <mark>{of=>}</mark> the computer <mark>{is=>has been}</mark> the most important technological event .
explanation_1:
- The article "a" is added before "doubt" to make the sentence grammatically correct.
- The phrase "discovering of the computer" is changed to "discovering the computer" to make the sentence more concise and fluent.
- "is" is changed to "has been" to show that the discovery of the computer was a past event with lasting impact.
explanation_2:
- "Doubt" is a noun and needs an article.
- If the phrasing was "the discovery of," "of" would be appropriate here. Because "discovering" is a transitive verb though, it requires a direct object, in this case "the computer."
- Because this event took place in the past, using a past tense conjugation for the verb makes more sense.

aligned: Although the data cover persecutions of all <mark>{religion=>religions}</mark> , <mark>{but=>}</mark> recently persecution of Ahmadis <mark>{are=>is}</mark> significant and hard , followed by persecution of Christians and <mark>{persecution of=>}</mark> other <mark>{Islam=>Islamic}</mark> sects <mark>{by=>}</mark> who claim <mark>{'=>to be "}</mark> genuine <mark>{/=>,}</mark> pure <mark>{/=>, and}</mark> fundamentalist Moslems <mark>{' .=>."}</mark>
explanation_1:
- "Religion" was changed to "religions" to make the sentence grammatically correct.
- "Are" was changed to "is" to match the singular subject "persecution."
- "Persecution of" was removed before "other" to make the sentence more concise.
- "Islam" was changed to "Islamic" to make the phrase grammatically correct.
- "By" was changed to "who" to make the sentence clearer and more concise.
- Quotation marks were added around the phrase "genuine, pure, and fundamentalist Moslems" to indicate that it is being quoted.
- Separators (commas) were added between the adjectives "genuine," "pure," and "fundamentalist" to make the sentence clearer.
- The period at the end of the sentence was changed to a closing quotation mark and a period to make the sentence grammatically correct.
explanation_2:
- "Religion" is replaced by its plural form because the determiner "all" that precedes it implies more than one.
- The conjunction "but" is inserted after the comma to properly combine two sentences.
- "Are" is replaced with "is" because the noun to which it refers, "persecution," is singular.
- "Persecution of" is removed because it is repetitive. The first instance of "persecution" is understood to apply to both the Christians and Islamic sets.
- "Islam" is replaced by its adjective form, "Islamic," in order to describe "sects."
- "By" is removed. This word is not needed here.
- "To be" is added before a series of adjectives. "To be" is an essential verb used to link descriptions to someone or something.
- The single quotation marks are replaced by double quotation marks, which is proper when quoting text.
- Forward slash marks are removed and replaced by commas to separate items in a list.
- The final quotation mark and period are switched in order. In American English, punctuation always appears within the quotation marks.

aligned: First of all , I do n't like and do n't enjoy spending endless hours pushing my <mark>{trolley=>cart}</mark> ( which , by the way , has <mark>{it 's=>its}</mark> own idea of where it <mark>{want 's=>wants}</mark> to go ) between other desperate people <mark>{=>'s}</mark> baskets , just to find that perfect tin of beans or <mark>{a=>}</mark> toothpaste <mark>{. Especially that=>, especially since}</mark> it is so hard to find anything in <mark>{a=>}</mark> modern , huge <mark>{and=>department stores}</mark> stuffed with lots of merchandise <mark>{department stores=>}</mark> .
explanation_1:
- "Trolley" was changed to "cart" as "cart" is the more common term in American English.
- "It's" was changed to "its" as "its" is the possessive form of "it."
- "Want's" was changed to "wants" as "wants" is the correct form of the verb.
- "Just to find that perfect tin of beans or a toothpaste" was changed to "just to find that perfect tin of beans or toothpaste" as "toothpaste" does not require an article.
- "Especially that it is so hard to find anything in a modern, huge and stuffed with lots of merchandise department stores" was changed to "especially since it is so hard to find anything in modern, huge department stores stuffed with lots of merchandise" as the latter is a clearer and more concise way of expressing the idea.
- "Desperate people baskets" was changed to "other desperate people's baskets" as "other desperate people" possess the baskets.
- "Department stores" was changed to "huge department stores" as the original sentence does not sufficiently describe the size of the stores.
explanation_2:
- Unnecessary edit.
- The possessive is spelled "its." "It's" is a contraction of "it" and "is."
- The correct spelling is "wants" with no apostrophe.
- The possessive ending should be used here.
- Toothpaste is a mass noun and should not have a singular indefinite article.
- This stylistic edit connects these two sentences to make the whole flow better.
- Because "department stores" is plural, it should not have a singular article.
- This edit moves where "department stores" is so that it is part of the correct prepositional phrase.

aligned: NOBODY <mark>{TELL=>TOLD}</mark> US ANYTHING ABOUT THE CHANGES , AND WE WANT <mark>{THAT=>}</mark> YOU <mark>{=>TO}</mark> GIVE US BACK <mark>{THE=>OUR}</mark> MONEY .
explanation_1:
- "Tell" is changed to "told" to match the past tense of "nobody" and make the sentence grammatically correct.
- "That" is deleted as it is unnecessary and awkward in this sentence.
- "That" is changed to "to" to make the sentence grammatically correct and more concise.
- "The" is changed to "our" to make the sentence more specific and personal.
explanation_2:
- The verb tense was changed from the present tense "tell" to the past tense "told" because the time frame is in the past.
- The phrase "we want that you give us back" is replaced with the phrase "we want you to give us back." The "that" is deleted, and "to" is added before the verb "give."  This is because the verb "want" usually takes a noun or pronoun as an object after it ("you") plus a verb in the to-infinitive form ("to give").
- The definite article is replaced with the first person plural possessive pronoun "our" to highlight who the money belongs to.

It was a Jaguar with Will Smith <mark>{on=>in}</mark> it <mark>{,=>.}</mark> I stopped and <mark>{I was going to ask=>asked}</mark> if he needed some help <mark>{=>,}</mark> and he said <mark>{=>,}</mark> " <mark>{of=>Of}</mark> course <mark>{=>.}</mark> " <mark>{.=>}</mark>
explanation_1:
- A comma was inserted after the introductory phrase "As you know" to separate it from the independent clause that follows.
- A period was used instead of a conjunction as the second clause is a complete sentence that contrasts with the first.
- "Lay-by" was changed to "shoulder" to reflect American English.
- "On" was changed to "in" to properly describe the location of Will Smith in the car.
- The phrase "I was going to ask" was changed to "asked" to reflect the action that actually occurred.
- The capitalization of "Of" was corrected to match proper English capitalization rules.
- A period was added to end the sentence.
explanation_2:
- A comma after "As you know" was added because this functions as an introductory phrase, and the comma separates the introductory phrase from the main clause.
- To improve fluency and clarity, the one long sentence was separated into two. The first sentence ends with the word "house" because this is one independent clause. The second sentence begins with the word "But," which is capitalized.
- A comma after "But that Sunday" was added because this functions as an introductory phrase, and the comma separates the introductory phrase from the main clause.
- The preposition "in" was replaced with "on" to refer to an object touching the surface of the road.
- The word "lay-by" was changed to "shoulder" to conform to American English vocabulary.
- The preposition "on" was replaced with "in" to carry the meaning "inside."
- To improve fluency and clarity, the one long sentence was separated into two. The first sentence ends with the word "it" because this is one independent clause. The second sentence begins with the word "I."
- The phrase "I was going to ask" was replaced with the verb "asked" to improve conciseness.
- A comma was inserted before "and" because "and" functions as a coordinating conjunction combining two independent clauses.
- A comma was added. We usually use a comma if the clause introducing a quotation is not independent.
- The letter "O" was capitalized because the first word of a quotation is capitalized.
- The period was placed before the closing quotation mark. In American English, commas and periods are placed inside the closing quotation marks.
- The period after the closing quotation mark was deleted.

- The word 'AT' should be capitalized in the beginning of the sentence for grammatical correctness.
- The word 'all' has been added to clarify that everyone needs to be back at 20:30.

aligned: <mark>{Althoug=>Although}</mark> I <mark>{wich=>wish}</mark> that my accommodation at Camp California <mark>{it must=>}</mark> be in tents <mark>{.=>,}</mark> I <mark>{get=>had that}</mark> experience <mark>{in the=>}</mark> last summer .
explanation_1:
- "Althoug" was corrected to "Although."
- "Wich" was corrected to "wish."
- "It must be" was changed to "be" to improve the sentence structure and sound more natural.
- A comma was added to separate the two clauses.
- "Get experience" was changed to "had that experience" to correct the verb tense and make the sentence more fluent.
- "In the" was removed as it is not necessary in this context.
explanation_2:
- "althoug" should be spelled "although."
- "wich" should be spelled "wish."
- "accommodation" and "it" are both acting as the subject of the same clause, so "it" has been removed, along with "must" which wouldn't fit without "it."
- The first clause is a dependent clause, so it must be joined to the following independent clause with a comma, not a period.
- "had that" makes more sense than "get"

- "Like" was removed because it is unnecessary and redundant with "such as."

aligned: In <mark>{=>the}</mark> World Cup <mark>{=>,}</mark> she debuted on December 3 , 2011 in Lillehammer <mark>{=>,}</mark> where she took <mark>{5nd=>5th}</mark> place .

- The missing article 'the' was added to make the sentence grammatically correct.
- A comma was added to separate the introductory phrase from the rest of the sentence.
- A comma was added after Lillehammer to separate the location from the following dependent clause.
- '5nd' is not a valid ordinal number, so it was corrected to '5th.'
explanation_2:
- 'The' was added in front of 'World Cup' because a determiner is required.
- A comma was added after 'World Cup.' An introductory clause must be followed by a comma if it has at least four words.
- A comma was inserted before 'where' to offset a relative cause.
- '5nd' was changed to '5th.' This is the correct abbreviation for this cardinal number.

- Removed "the" before "TV" to change the sense of the word from the count noun referring to the physical object to the more general mass noun metonymically referring to television programming.

aligned: <mark>{For me my opinions=>My opinion}</mark> on this <mark>{one=>}</mark> is true <mark>{=>:}</mark> it <mark>{is=>'s}</mark> boring <mark>{, it=>. This}</mark> might <mark>{=>be}</mark> because I am a boy .
explanation_1:
- Removed redundant "for me" and changed "opinions" to singular, as only one opinion is being discussed.
- Removed "one." "This" can function as a noun, making "one" superfluous.
- Inserted a colon to separate an explanatory clause.
- Replaced a comma with a period to separate two independent clauses, and replaced "it" with "This" to be more specific. "This" has a deictic aspect, meaning it "points" to something, in this case, the previous sentence.
- Added "be" because the modal "might" does not fill the necessity the clause has for a verb.
explanation_2:
- The first edit removes the unnecessary repetition of "me" and "opinions" and simplifies the sentence by making it singular.
- A colon is added to create a clearer separation between the statement of the opinion and the explanation for it.
- The use of contractions and the change in punctuation make the sentence more conversational and natural-sounding.

aligned: Because <mark>{=>of}</mark> this situation <mark>{=>,}</mark> I <mark>{=>'ll}</mark> be very busy on the first week of <mark>{july , and=>July .}</mark> I <mark>{apreciate=>'ll appreciate it}</mark> if you can give me the choice to start my " Camp California " <mark>{from=>on}</mark> July 10th .
explanation_1:
- "Because of" is used instead of "Because" to indicate cause and effect more clearly.
- A comma is added to separate the introductory clause from the main clause.
- The future tense "I'll" is used to indicate a request.
- "july , and" is corrected to "July." to follow capitalization rules and improve readability.
- "appreciate" is changed to "appreciate it" to use the complete idiom in English.
- "from" is changed to "on" because the preposition "on" is more commonly used with dates in English.
explanation_2:
- 'Of' is inserted here because 'because' cannot just take a noun phrase and be grammatical. The addition of 'of' as a preposition makes this clause grammatical.
- This comma is added because if 'because' begins a clause at the beginning of a sentence, that clause needs a comma.
- This edit conjugates the verb into the future tense as opposed to just being an infinitive, which would be ungrammatical in this context.
- This edit capitalizes the month 'July,' and separates the one original sentence into two for stylistic reasons.
- This edit corrects the spelling of 'appreciate,' and makes it future tense to better fit the context; this edit also adds an 'it,' which is standard for this expression.
- 'On' is the more appropriate preposition to use for the date something starts.

aligned: Shopping is concerned <mark>{that=>with}</mark> people <mark>{exchange from=>exchanging}</mark> money to <mark>{=>meet}</mark> their <mark>{demands=>needs}</mark> .
explanation_1:
- The preposition 'with' is more appropriate in this context than 'that.'
- 'Exchanging' is the appropriate verb here to convey the act of giving money for goods or services.
- 'Meet' better conveys the idea of fulfilling one's needs or desires.
- 'Demands' is a bit too strong in this context, as it implies a sense of entitlement or insistence.
explanation_2:
- The word "that" was replaced with "with" because "concerned with (something)" is an idiomatic phrase.
- The incorrect phrase "exchange from" was replaced with the word "exchanging."
- The verb "meet" was added because there is a "to" before it, indicating a verb in the infinitive form, "to meet."
- The noun "demands" was replaced with "needs" because this lexical choice is a more suitable equivalent.

aligned: Secondly , I <mark>{suppose=>supposed}</mark> the show <mark>{will=>would}</mark> start at 19 : 30 , but it started <mark>{t=>at}</mark> 20 : 15 .

- The verb tense was changed from the present tense "suppose" to the past tense "supposed" because the time frame described is in the past.
- The modal auxiliary "will" is changed to "would" because "will" conveys future tense, while the sentence refers to an event that has already begun.
- The spelling error was corrected. The correct spelling is "at."
explanation_2:
- 'Suppose' should be changed to 'supposed' to match the past tense of 'started' later in the sentence.
- 'Will' should be changed to 'would' because the sentence is talking about a past event from the perspective of the present.
- 'T' should be changed to 'at' to correct the spelling error.

aligned: When <mark>{all=>}</mark> the <mark>{=>whole}</mark> family <mark>{get=>got}</mark> up , I told <mark>{us=>them}</mark> the <mark>{true=>truth ,}</mark> and <mark>{all=>everyone}</mark> promised to say nothing .

- "When all the family get up" was changed to "When the whole family got up" for grammatical correctness and to match the past tense of the rest of the sentence.
- "I told us" was changed to "I told them" to match the correct pronoun and improve fluency.
- "true" was changed to "truth" for grammatical correctness.
- A comma was added after "truth" to separate the two independent clauses.
- "all" was changed to "everyone" for improved fluency.
explanation_2:

- The first-person plural object pronoun "us" was replaced with the third-person form "them" because the verb used is "tell," and this requires that the pronoun coming after it excludes the speaker.
- The adjective "true" was replaced with the noun "truth" because the article "the" comes before it, which typically means a noun is needed.
- The word "all" was replaced with the word "everyone" because this lexical choice is a more suitable equivalent.

aligned: This will be in the Casino Hotel <mark>{=>,}</mark> and we do n't need to worry <mark>{for=>about}</mark> the best way because <mark>{in=>}</mark> all the main routes in Devonport have signs with <mark>{=>the}</mark> correct way to the popular hotel .

- "for" was corrected to "about" to match the correct preposition.
- "in" was removed because it did not make sense in the context.
- "the" was added to match the correct article.

aligned: The other bad point was the <mark>{=>starting}</mark> time <mark>{when the show started , it=>. It}</mark> was already 20 : 15 when the first star <mark>{entred on=>entered}</mark> the scene , but your advertisement <mark>{sayed 19.30=>said 19 : 30}</mark> !

- "The time when the show started" is redundant and can be simplified to "the starting time."
- The second clause should be its own sentence for clarity and fluency.
- The misspelling "entred" was corrected to "entered."
- The incorrect spelling "sayed" was corrected to "said," and the time format was corrected to use a colon instead of a period.
explanation_2:
- The first sentence was revised to replace "when the show started" with "starting" as an adjective before "time" in order to increase conciseness and brevity.
- A period was inserted before "it," and "it" was capitalized. Both of these changes were made to eliminate a run-on sentence error.
- "Entred" should be spelled "entered."
- "On" was removed because a preposition is not necessary in this phrase.

- "The" was added before "last" to indicate a specific year.
- "Years" was changed to "year's" to show possession.
- "Estate" was changed to "real estate" to provide more clarity and specificity.

aligned: Brian <mark>{learm=>learned}</mark> what <mark>{was=>had}</mark> happened <mark>{=>,}</mark> and at first he was angry with Pat <mark>{=>,}</mark> but then he thanked him .
explanation_1:
- "Learned" is the correct past tense form of "learn."
- "Had" is used to indicate that the action of "what happened" occurred before the action of "learned."
- A comma is necessary to separate the two independent clauses.
- A comma is necessary to separate the two clauses in the compound sentence.
explanation_2:
- "learm" was changed to "learned" because that is the correct form for past tense.
- "was" was changed to "had" because that is the correct collocation.
- A comma was added before "and" and "but" because commas are added before conjunctions that conjoin independent clauses.

- The spelling of 'organized' was corrected to the American English spelling.
- The verb 'sets' is a better fit for the intended meaning than 'puts.'

aligned: It is very easy because there are a lot of things to buy <mark>{, shops are=>. Stores have}</mark> plenty of every <mark>{kinds=>kind}</mark> of <mark>{things=>thing}</mark> .

- "Things" was changed to "thing" to match the singular noun "kind" that precedes.

- Because 'every' is being used here, 'kind' and 'thing' should be singular.

- The phrase "with a number of people" was used to replace "of numerous people."

- The word "if" was replaced with "of" because the phrase references a date and month,  "25th of July."
- A comma was added after the introductory prepositional phrase, which provides background information for the independent clause following it.
- The proper name was replaced with the pronoun "he" because the name was already mentioned.
explanation_2:
- "if" is changed to "of" because "of" is the correct preposition to use when referring to a specific date.
- A comma is added after the date because it separates the introductory phrase from the main clause.
- "Jesse" is changed to "he" because it is more concise and clear.

aligned: <mark>{The=>If the}</mark> door <mark>{it is broken=>breaks}</mark> , we can replace it <mark>{rapidly=>quickly ,}</mark> and it <mark>{is not=>wo n't be}</mark> expensive <mark>{when=>, since}</mark> it <mark>{is=>'s}</mark> plastic .
explanation_1:
- "Rapidly" was changed to "quickly" since "quickly" is the appropriate lexical term.
- "The" was changed to "if the" in order to present a hypothetical situation, which requires a conditional sentence (If the). The general form of this sentence begins with "if the" and takes the present tense form of the verb (breaks).
- "Is not" is replaced with "won't be." The conditional sentence requires the won't + infinitive verb form.
- "When" is replaced by "since" to correct a lexical error.
explanation_2:
- The phrase "the door" was changed to "if the door" to make the sentence more conditional.
- The redundant pronoun "it" was removed to improve sentence fluency.
- "Rapidly" was changed to "quickly" to improve word choice.
- "Is not" was changed to "won't be" to improve sentence fluency and to show the negative aspect of the cost.
- "When" was changed to "since" to make the causal relationship clearer.
- The contraction "it's" was used instead of "it is" to improve sentence fluency.

explanation_2:

- A semicolon is used instead of a comma to separate two independent clauses.
- "Turn it in" was changed to "turn it into" to convey the idea of transforming something into another thing.

aligned: I want you to know <mark>{how=>about the}</mark> extraordinary moments I <mark>{passed=>had}</mark> with my friends <mark>{in=>at}</mark> the festival .

- "About" replaced "how."
- "The" was added to show the noun "moments" refers to something specific, not general.

aligned: If you <mark>{would=>}</mark> ask me , I prefer my friends to do all <mark>{shoping=>my shopping}</mark> for me <mark>{. Because=>, because}</mark> I <mark>{=>'m}</mark> aware of <mark>{big=>long}</mark> lines to check <mark>{point=>out}</mark> , crowds of people , noise ...
explanation_1:
- 'Would' is not necessary in this sentence; 'ask' is enough to convey the meaning.
- 'Shopping' needs a possessive pronoun, 'my', to indicate that it is the speaker's shopping.
- 'Because' needs to be preceded by a comma to separate the dependent and independent clauses.
- 'Big' is replaced with 'long' to better convey the idea of waiting in line.
- 'Point' is replaced with 'out' to better convey the idea of completing the transaction.
- An apostrophe and 'm' are added to 'I' to indicate the contraction 'I'm' for 'I am'.
explanation_2:
- The word "would" was removed because in this case it introduces the sense of an imaginary future world, whereas the intention makes more sense with a sense of the present.
- The word "shopping" was corrected for spelling and the word "my" was inserted to clarify whose shopping it is.
- The adjective "big" was replaced with "long" for clarity because "big" refers to the physical size of members of the line, whereas "long" refers to how many people are lined up.

- 'Had' is used instead of 'has' because the situation happened in the past. A past participle is needed when referring to an ongoing situation in the past that did not carry on to the present.
- A comma and 'and' was removed and replaced by a period. Additionally, 'suddenly' was capitalized. These changes were combined to create a separation between two complete sentences.

In}</mark> my opinion <mark>{=>,}</mark> if I choose the log cabins it will be like <mark>{be=>being}</mark> at home .

- A comma was inserted after "In my opinion" as prepositional phrases require when at the beginning of a sentence.
- "Be" was changed to "being" as the gerund form is required to make a noun phrase.
explanation_2:
- "Choise" was corrected to "choice."

- "Be" was changed to "being" to create proper verb tense agreement.

- A closing quotation mark was added to complement the opening quotation mark.

aligned: <mark>{At=>In}</mark> the end <mark>{=>,}</mark> I would like to say that my evening out two days <mark>{before=>ago}</mark> was not perfect <mark>{=>,}</mark> and I <mark>{wold=>would}</mark> be <mark>{glad=>happy}</mark> if you could <mark>{pay=>refund some of}</mark> my <mark>{some=>}</mark> money <mark>{back=>}</mark> .

- A comma was added after the introductory phrase.
- "Two days before" was changed to "two days ago" to make it more clear and specific.
- "Glad" was changed to "happy" to convey a more positive sentiment.
- "Pay my some money back" was changed to "refund some of my money" to use more standard phrasing.
- "Some" was removed from "my some money" as it is redundant.
- "Back" was removed from "pay my some money back" as it is unnecessary and redundant with "refund."
explanation_2:
- "At" replaced with "in." This is the correct preposition to use in this phrase.
- Commas are usually added after phrases like "in the end" at the beginning of a sentence.
- Comma added between two clauses joined by "and."
- Spelling of "would" corrected.
- Stylistic edit: "glad" replaced with "happy."
- "pay back" replaced with "refund" for conciseness.
- "some" moved before "my." This word needs to go before phrases like "my money."
- "of" inserted after "some." This word is required to go with "some" in this context.
